title: 111_s591
content:
The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission for the purposes of addressing high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel. The commission's composition, duties, powers, staff, compensation, security clearances, reports, and termination are outlined in the Act. The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission to evaluate potential improvements in the management of high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel. The commission is tasked with submitting a report to Congress containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations to improve the management of defense waste, spent nuclear fuel, high-level waste, and commercial radioactive waste. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders in consultation with relevant committees. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by leaders in consultation with relevant committees. One member is appointed jointly by the majority leader of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Appointees must not be involved in certain activities or hold specific government positions. They should be prominent US citizens with expertise in engineering. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by leaders with expertise in engineering, relevant fields, and governmental service. Appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with the Chairperson appointed from the members. The Commission will meet as soon as possible after enactment, with subsequent meetings called by the Chairperson or majority members. A quorum of five members is required for meetings. Quorum of five members required for Commission meetings. Vacancies filled in same manner as original appointment. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's spent fuel and high-level waste strategies, including transferring responsibility to a Government corporation, providing necessary authority and funding for storage and management, and exploring cost-sharing options. The Commission is evaluating cost-sharing options for nuclear fuel management technology, establishing interim storage facilities, researching advanced fuel cycle technologies, and transferring spent nuclear fuel inventories to the Department of Energy. The Act requires the transfer of spent nuclear fuel inventories to at-reactor dry casks after 7 years of storage in a cooling pond. It also mandates permanent deep geologic disposal for civilian and defense wastes. The Commission will consult with various stakeholders and submit recommendations on the disposition of fees charged to nuclear energy ratepayers, as well as the management of spent nuclear fuel. The Commission will analyze the financial impacts of its recommendations on the contractual liability of the Federal Government under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 and submit a final report to Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and enter into contracts to fulfill its duties under the Act. It can also obtain information from federal agencies for the purposes of the Act. The Commission can request information from federal agencies, which must be provided in a timely manner. Information handling must comply with applicable laws. The General Services Administration will assist the Commission as needed. The Commission can request administrative support and services from General Services on a reimbursable basis. Other federal departments and agencies can also provide additional support as requested and authorized by law. The Commission is allowed to use the United States mails like other government entities. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission, and staff is also addressed. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint staff without following certain federal employment rules, with a salary limit. Staff director and personnel are considered federal employees. The Commission staff director and personnel are federal employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Members of the Commission are not included in this classification. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, retaining their rights and privileges. The Commission can also procure consultant services as needed. The Commission can procure consultant services from experts and consultants under specific regulations, with rates not exceeding those of a person at level IV of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 9. Compensation for Commission members may not exceed the daily equivalent of level IV of the Executive Schedule. Travel expenses are allowed for Commission members while performing duties. SEC. 10. Commission members are eligible for security clearances. SEC. 10. Security clearances are provided to Commission members and staff by Federal agencies to access classified information, following existing procedures and requirements. SEC. 11. REPORTS.

The Commission must release an interim report within 1 year and a final report within 2 years of its first meeting. The final report will include findings, conclusions, recommendations agreed upon by the majority, dissenting opinions with explanations, and consideration of public comments. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of the Act, with funds available until expended. The Commission's authority terminates 180 days after the final report submission, during which it can conclude its activities and disseminate the final report.
